Re: License #: CI790296492

Dear Mr. HANNAH:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. No
substantial violations were found.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.
Sincerely,
Rorie Dodge-Pifer, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS/DCWL

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CI790296492
Licensee Group Organization: Wolverine Human Services
Licensee Designee: Judith Wollack
Chief Administrator: BRANDON HANNAH
Agency Name: VASSAR HOUSE
Agency Address: 955 COMMERCE DR
VASSAR, MI 48768-8954
License Status: 1st Provisional
License Expiration Date: 09/10/2023
Capacity: 70

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4142 Health services; policies and procedures.
Section (1) An institution shall establish and follow written health service
Description policies and procedures addressing all of the following:
(a) Routine and emergency medical, and dental, and behavioral
health care.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation When youth previously resided at facility, one youth had stomach
aches often and was threatened with write-ups for self-harm when
they would vomit. Youth saw the nurse, but never a doctor. When
youth previously resided at the facility, they were fed food that
they were allergic to, resulting in allergic reactions.
Investigation Interviews:
During Youth A’s interview at her school on 4/26/23 for another
investigation, Youth A reported she was sick every morning while
at the facility. She said she threw up and the staff would tell her it
was self-harm. This started in December and continued until she
left in March. She complained about it every day. She did see the
nurse who said she was fine and gave her Pepto. Any time Youth
3

A would write a med complaint it was up to the medical staff if they
felt it was necessary to see her or not. It always took too long for
the girls to be seen by the nurse or a doctor. Youth A said her
stomach is better now that she is home. Youth A also reported
Youth B had food allergies and would have reactions after eating.
She said the facility would have to give Youth B an Epi-pen a few
times because they were feeding her food she was allergic to and
her throat would swell up. Youth B also threw up all the time.
Youth C was interviewed face to face at her current placement by
a courtesy DHHS Worker on 5/3/23. This consultant participated
by phone. Youth C reported Youth B had food allergies and the
facility did not do anything to find out what they were. When Youth
B would have hives, get red, and throw up, staff would sometimes
stab her with an epi-pen and other times they would just let her
throw up. Eventually they started to call an ambulance for her.
An interview was attempted with Youth B at the home of a friend
on 5/10/23. She refused to be interviewed.
Youth F was interviewed face to face at her school on 5/19/23 by
a courtesy DHHS Worker. This consultant participated in the
interview by phone. She reported Youth B had allergic reactions
and would throw up every time she ate. They used an epi-pen on
her a couple of times and called an ambulance. Youth F reported
the facility would provide Youth B with alternative foods.
Youth J was interviewed face to face at her current placement on
5/24/23. Youth J stated Youth B was allergic to something but
would eat it anyway. She had to go to the hospital and get
medicine. Youth B's face would break out when this happened.
They were not sure what foods she was allergic to. She did not
know if anyone else was sick from the food. Youth B went to the
hospital every time she ate something she was not supposed to
eat. Youth J reported Youth B was given other options to eat but
she would choose the ones that made her sick.
Youth H was interviewed face to face at her school on 5/31/23.
She reported any youth who had food allergies would be given
other food.
A three-way phone call occurred with Nurse, the DHHS Worker,
and this consultant on 6/5/23. Nurse stated she no longer worked
at the facility. She reported there was a youth who complained of
stomach issues and decreased appetite, but she could not recall
her name. The youth was scheduled with the Nurse Practitioner
4

(NP) two or three times. Nurse was asked if it may have been
Youth A and she stated the name did not sound familiar. Nurse
also recalled Youth B having allergic reactions while at the facility.
The first time it happened Youth B was sent out by ambulance
and then was scheduled to meet with the Nurse Practitioner.
Youth B was also given an Epi-pen. Youth B had to go to the
Emergency Room (ER) any time the Epi-pen was used. Youth B
needed bloodwork for allergy testing but Youth B could not do it.
An allergy appointment was scheduled but was cancelled by the
allergy clinic due to a snowstorm. Testing was rescheduled and
completed but Nurse left the facility before results came in. Youth
B would vomit immediately after eating Funyuns and her face
would get flushed. Youth B never had any airway issues during
these episodes. Youth B refused to use the Epi-pen multiple
times. Nurse reported that the kitchen staff made significant
changes to Youth B's menu to help alleviate the reactions and
narrow down what may have been causing them.
Nurse reported when the youth completed med complaints she
would review them and depending on the nature of the complaint
she may have seen the youth that day, or others if non-urgent
they would triage them. She would typically see youth within 1-2
days of getting a complaint. She would assess the situation and
provide over the counter medication or put the youth on the list to
see NP. NP was at the facility every Tuesday. If the situation were
emergent, then the youth would be sent out to the ER. She
reported the youth complete the med complaint, give it to the staff
to either e-mail it to the medical department or put in a lock box
that she would check every Monday - Friday. She reported the
complaints did not always end up in the box.
Staff 1 was interviewed face to face at his current place of
employment on 5/31/23. Staff 1 reported he worked at the facility
from July of 2022 until March. He reported when Youth B came to
the facility, she did not have any allergies listed. They were not
aware of any food allergies until Youth B had to use an Epi-pen.
Staff 1 heard Youth B ate Funyuns then had to go to the hospital
due to an allergic reaction. This happened at snack time, and he
was not there. A week later he did not give her Funyuns, but she
still had a reaction. They tried limiting her diet, but it did not work.
He didn’t think it made sense because she was eating fine when
she first arrived at the facility. One time Youth B had a reaction,
and she refused her Epi-pen so they called an ambulance. It took
a few months to get Youth B in for allergy testing. Staff 1 reported
that no one ever told Youth B she had to eat items she was
allergic to. She did not want to eat the food she was given. He
5

would serve her hot dogs, grilled chicken breast, and hamburger
without the bun.
Staff 3 was interviewed via three-way phone call with this
consultant and the DHHS Worker on 6/7/23. Staff 3 stated she is
the Director of Operations and oversees the kitchens at the
facility. Staff 3 recalled Youth B and her allergic reactions. She
could not remember specifics about the reactions but knew Youth
B had an Epi-pen and she was scheduled for an allergy test.
Youth B was brought up during the facility's morning rounds in
which she participated in, so she was informed of Youth B's issues
from those meetings. They were baffled about what was causing
the reactions. They tried Youth B on a gluten free, dairy free, corn
free, nut free, fish free diet. Then Youth B was pulled out of the
cafeteria and ate her meals separate from everyone else in case
the allergen was airborne. Youth B would eat with staff in a
classroom or on the unit. Youth B did get tested for allergies but
Youth B left the facility shortly afterwards. She thought the allergy
test showed minor allergies to dairy.
Staff 2 was interviewed face to face by another consultant and this
consultant participated by phone. Staff 2 is a cook at the facility.
Staff 2 reported they accommodate any food allergies. They are
told of the allergies by the nurse and get a paper that indicates the
allergies or special diet. He did recall Youth B having allergic
reactions to food but they did not know what she was allergic to so
they treated her like she was allergic to everything. He said she
was tested and found out she was allergic to pepper and garlic.
He did not see any allergic reactions as he was working in a
different kitchen at the time.
The DHHS Worker called on 6/29/23 to report she talked to the
NP who stated she saw Youth B on 1/31/23 and 2/21/23. They did
in office allergy testing which is not as extensive as the one done
by the allergy clinic. The in office test showed a slight allergy to
cow’s milk. Youth B was sent to an allergist. She did not have any
concerns about staff not following-up on Youth B's appointments.
Staff 4 was interviewed by three-way phone call on 6/29/23. She
worked at the facility from January of 2023 until April. She was the
program manager during that time. She did remember Youth B
having issues with possible food allergies. She was sent for
testing and would eat separate from everyone else, but the testing
showed she was not allergic to the foods she had eaten before the
reactions. Staff 4 reported Youth B was not made to eat food she
could not eat. The kitchen provided alternative food for her.
6

Youth G was interviewed by video conferencing on 6/7/23. She
stated she has food allergies and she once had a reaction to the
food. She was given Benadryl and told to use her Epi-pen. She
reported Youth B also got sick from the food. Youth B was
throwing up after she ate anything. She was given an Epi-pen and
an ambulance was called almost every time she had a reaction.
When Youth B would throw up she would say she is throwing up
for a reason but the staff did not listen. She said this happened to
Youth B once or twice. Youth G reported she didn’t eat much
while at the facility because she has a lot of food allergies so they
would feed her the same things over and over again. She said
they had a new cook but could not remember his name. She said
she was allergic to wheat, peanuts, soy and shellfish that she
could remember. They provided her with beef stew and said if she
did not eat it she would get written up for it. Both the new cook
and the staff told her this. She had an allergic reaction with bumps
all over her. She was given Benadryl and told to use her Epi-pen.
She told the staff she was allergic to the food before she ate it and
she told the cook after she ate it that she was allergic to it. She
was given an alternative to eat but it had veggies in it and she
does not like veggies. This was the only time she had beef stew.
They did not serve it to her after that.
Staff 5 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 6/21/23. She
reported none of the youth ever complained to her about not
getting medical treatment. The youth could write a med complaint
and let staff know and staff would log it and tell the supervisor
about the complaint. A lady would come to the unit each day and
collect the med complaints. As far as she knew the med
complaints were followed up on. Staff 5 could not remember
Youth A. She did remember Youth B. Youth B would eat
something and her allergies would flare up. The logbook would
say Youth B received treatment. They did not know what food she
was allergic to. Staff 5 stated Youth B would get mad about
getting different food than the others and she would throw it away.
Staff 6 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 6/21/23. She
stated she did not know about any issues with youth not getting
medical treatment. She was unaware of any medical issues with
Youth A. She reported out of nowhere Youth B would breakout
and throw-up after eating. She was given an Epi-pen and taken to
the hospital. It took a while for Youth B to get her allergy test
because there was not an allergist available. She did not have any
other youth get sick from eating. Some youth would refuse to eat
and they would write up a med refusal for it. Youth A was one who
7

would not eat. Staff 6 said Youth A had a lot of emotional issues
and this was why she did not eat. Staff 6 said if the girls had to
have a special diet a list would be given to the cooks so they could
provide the girls with the appropriate food. Youth B would sneak
food items from her peers. Youth B then had to eat away from the
others in a different room.
A case conference was held with the DHHS Worker on 7/10/23.
The DHHS Worker indicated she would not have any findings.
Documentation reviewed:
• DHHS Worker’s notes from her conversation with the
allergy clinic on 5/25/23: Youth B had an appointment at
their office on 3/8/23 were she tested positive for mild food
allergies. Symptoms to include hives and upset stomach
but her allergies were not severe enough to cause
anaphylaxis. The doctor did not have any concerns about
Youth B’s care at the facility.
• E-mail from Administrative Assistant on 5/30/23: There
were not any med complaints or grievances filed by Youth
B.
• Youth B Face Sheet: Youth B was listed to have seasonal
allergies upon her admission to the facility.
• Youth A Face sheet: Youth A was listed to be allergic to
trees, grass, and pollen.
• Youth B medical documentation: Youth A saw a Nurse
Practitioner on 1/31/23, 2/14/23, 2/21/23 and the ER on
1/26/23, 2/10/23, and 2/12/23.
• Youth B’s Allergy Test Results: A skin test was completed
on Youth A on 3/8/23 at an allergy clinic. She tested
positive for celery, oat, onion, garlic, tomato, shrimp,
lobster, and crab. All scores were either a 1 or 2 out of 4 for
severity.
• Youth B med complaints: 2/6/23 Youth B stated since
starting her medication she has been vomiting and throwing
up. She was seen by NP for follow-up. Another one dated
2/17/23 stated Youth B could not keep any food down.
Follow-up scheduled with NP.
• Youth A medical documents: she saw NP on 10/4/22,
11/22/22, and 1/3/23. None of the documentation from the
visits list any complaints about vomiting.
• Youth B Incident Reports: 1/26 Youth B’s face turning red
and her chest hurt, she was given Benadryl but threw it up
so an ambulance was called; 2/4 Youth B threw up after
taking medication and given Pepto; 2/7 Youth B threw up
shortly after eating, nothing further was done; 2/10 Youth B
8

threw up and face swelled after eating, she was sent by
ambulance to the ER; 2/12 Youth B threw up multiple times
and went to ER; 2/13 Youth B throwing up back to back,
monitored; 2/27 Youth B threw up several times after
dinner, given medication for vomiting.
• Kitchen Production records: records maintained by the
kitchen showed that all food was up to temperature before
it was serves and Youth B had her own menu.
Analysis From documentation reviewed and interviews conducted there
was no indication Youth A reported any stomach issues while at
the facility. Further documentation shows Youth B did receive
medical treatment for potential allergic reactions.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4149 Resident nutrition.
Section (1) A licensee shall provide a minimum of 3 nutritious edible meals
Description daily unless medically contraindicated and documented.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation When youth previously resided at facility, they were fed raw
chicken.
Investigation Interviews:
During Youth A’s interview she said she thought it was the food at
the facility that was making her sick. They were fed uncooked
chicken that was pink and slimy. A lot of kids were getting sick
from the food especially Youth F.
Youth C reported the food at the facility was nasty and uncooked.
Staff 1 gave the youth a bloody piece of chicken. The girls told the
staff and the staff said they would tell the supervisor. The youth
were not given anything in its place.
During her interview Youth H said the cook, Staff 1, would give
them raw chicken breasts. The girls told him he did not cook it
long enough. She said this happened a couple of times and
always with Staff 1. She said they were once served raw cake
batter. A couple of youth threw up from the food. She could not
remember who those youth were. The girls would tell staff, but
staff would be tired of hearing about it. If the staff would talk to
Staff 1 about it he would just walk away from them or give
excuses. Staff 4 talked to him at one point. Staff 4 said the food
was disgusting. They always had salad bar and peanut butter and
jelly (PB&J) or Uncrustables as another option. Sometimes the
bread was moldy or the Uncrustables were soaked through. If the
9

youth would show the cook that the bread was moldy they would
be given a new one.
During her interview Youth F reported Staff 1 would cook chicken
and it would be raw when he served it. This happened multiple
times.
Youth J reported there were times when the food at the facility
was not fully cooked. Staff 1 said he cooked the chicken to 170
degrees. When Staff 1 found out the chicken was uncooked he
threw the raw pieces away. Not all pieces were raw. Youth J said
this happened a few times. The girls could get PB&J as an
alternative. If there was no PB&J then Youth J would just not eat.
She said it was not just the chicken that was uncooked it was
other food as well. The supervisors were informed of the issue.
Once Staff 1 was no longer working the food was no longer
uncooked.
Youth D was interviewed face to face in her home by a Courtesy
DHHS Worker on 5/2/23. This consultant was not notified of the
interview until after it occurred. The DHHS Worker forwarded her
notes which stated Youth D reported it was a common occurrence
for the food not to be cooked appropriately. She said for example
they were all given chicken that was raw and undercooked and
when they discovered there was an issue, they did not provide an
alternative food option for the night. A message was left for Youth
D’s father to schedule a follow-up interview, but no response was
received.
Staff 1 reported the food they provide for the youth comes to them
pre-cooked. He said they are not allowed to serve raw meat. They
rarely used raw meat. He stated they did serve chicken leg
quarters that had to be up to temperature prior to them being
served. He would always make sure the chicken was at 170
degrees even though it only had to be 165 degrees. Staff 1 said
he never served raw chicken. The youth knew how to work the
system. If they did not get what they wanted the youth would then
write a grievance.
Staff 3 stated she creates the menus and trains the kitchen staff.
The menus are based on the school breakfast and lunch
guidelines from the Michigan Department of Education. They
provide 5-week rotating menus. One for summer and one for
winter. The menus are posted in the cafeteria. She received input
from the youth in creating the menus. Staff 3 said they order their
food from Gordon's Food Service. If there are special dietary
10

needs then she will go out to the health food store or other stores
and get substitutes. Most of the food they receive is precooked.
They heat all poultry to 165 degrees. They do have chicken leg
quarters every 5 weeks on the winter menu that are not pre-
cooked. Staff are to cook the leg quarters to 165 degrees before
serving. They follow the packaging for cooking time and check the
temperature. Staff 3 said she never received any complaints about
uncooked food or staff not following the guidelines. The staff
complete production records that show what the staff fixed for the
youth each day. None of the youth were forced to eat uncooked
food. She did not have any concerns with Staff 1. She would do
periodic walk-throughs and complete temperature checks and
never had any issues. Youth always complain they do not like the
food so she would have them suggest an alternative for her to put
on the menu. She did not have any complaints about food making
people sick. She reported at the bottom of the menu it lists an
alternative as PB&J which is always an option for the youth. They
also put a salad bar out for all lunch and dinners.
Staff 2 reported most of the food they serve is pre-cooked. The
only items not pre-cooked are leg quarters and stew meat. The
chicken breast and chicken legs are pre-cooked. He said he cooks
all meat to 165 degrees even if it says 145 degrees. He reported
he never heard any complaints about uncooked food when he was
cooking. The youth can ask for an alternative option if they do not
want to eat what is served. Staff 2 said he keeps his thermometer
with him.
Staff 4 reported she always had youth and staff complaining about
the food but there was nothing said about the food being
uncooked and there were no complaints about youth getting ill
from the food. A staff (she could not remember who) reported to
her there was an issue with the salad bar. She talked to Staff 2
about the issue and checked the dates on the food. There were no
issues. She said the staff did not feel well and they thought it was
from the salad bar.
Youth G reported some of the meat that was provided was raw.
She said it was always the new cook who served the raw meat.
When this would happen she would throw the meat away and not
eat it. One of Youth G's peers (she could not remember who) told
the new cook that the meat was raw but he did not say anything.
The youth could have PB&J or salad bar instead, but the cook
would get mad if they asked for PB&J.
11

Staff 5 reported the girls always complained about the food, but
they would eat it. If they did not want what was offered, they could
get a PB&J. She did not recall any youth getting sick after eating.
Staff 6 reported a lot of the youth did not like the food Staff 1 and
Staff 2 made. If they did not like the food, they could ask for PB&J.
The youth would complain about food not being done. They said
the burgers were pink so the cooks would re-cook the food. The
baked chicken would sometimes look undone. She herself would
not eat it. The youth always had another option to choose. She
said this would only happen with Staff 1 and Staff 2. If the food
looked undercooked the youth would not eat it.
Documents Reviewed:
• Staff 1 file: Staff 1 did not have any disciplines in his file.
• Menus: Winter menu weeks 1-5 were reviewed. Chicken
breast were served 3 times during the 5 week period,
chicken legs twice. The bottom of the menu states PB&J
can be a substitution and salad bar is offered for lunch and
dinner every day.
Analysis Based on interviews with staff and review of documentation there
is no indication the youth were made to eat uncooked chicken.
Consultation:
The agency should review with cooking staff requirements of
cooking meat to the correct temperature and checking prior to
serving as most youth and one staff reported they saw meat that
was undercooked.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
It is recommended no change be made to the CCI license.
7/25/23
______________________________________
Rorie Dodge-Pifer Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
July 24, 2023____
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
12
